newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Fed's McDonough says CPI target up to Congress.
newsitem.headline: Fed's McDonough says CPI target up to Congress.

text.p: New York Federal Reserve president William McDonough said on Tuesday that any specific inflation target range as a monetary policy goal would have to be decided by the U.S. Congress.
"I have suggested that there might be a range but that should be decided by Congress," McDonough told a news conference in Hong Kong.
Some economists have suggested that the Fed should have a specific inflation goal rather simply seeking price stability.
McDonough reiterated his suggestion of a 0.5 to 2.0 percent target range for annual retail inflation.
But McDonough said risking a weaker U.S. economy just to push down the inflation rate a few tenths of a percentage point would be inappropriate.
McDonough said the present level of consumer price inflation (CPI) at just under three percent "might be somewhat higher than what most people would consider price stability".
But he noted that the way CPI was calculated tended to overstate actual inflation. A committee studying this phenomenon was expected to release a report on Wednesday, he said.
McDonough said if the study showed that inflation is lower than the CPI indicates, then the United States may already be at levels of inflation consistent with price stability.
"If it isn't, then we are still close," he said.
With inflation relatively low, McDonough indicated actively trying to push it down further may not be appropriate.
"It is not appropriate to risk a weakening in the economy for driving the CPI down a few tenths of a percentage point," he said.
